bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Henry Rose Carter, January 5, 1922

div1.p: Noguchi discusses the death of Cross in Mexico, emphasizing the limited protection of vaccination.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Henry Rose Carter, January 5, 1922
div1.opener:
Int H. B.
Noguchi
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
January 5, 1922
My dear General Carter:
div1.p:
I thank you for your kind letter of January 3. I hope
that the principles of the treatment of yellow fever given by you
will be more rigidly adhered to by those who come in contact with
yellow fever cases. I think the “tripod” expression is a very good
one to remember -- at least three things have to be respected.

Doctor Cross did not die in Tuxtepec. He was taken ill
there on December 18th or 19th and brought back to Veracruz on De-
cember 23, where he died at noon, December 26th. These are the data
received not only from a telegraphic communication from Doctor Cald-
well but also his report on Doctor Cross's case, which I received in
this morning's mail. Regarding the loss of the immunity -- If you
inject a second dose of vaccine 10 or 11 days after the first, it re-
moves the immune bodies from the body; this is the general rule in
immunity. The processess of vaccination, as you say, has to be
repeated.

The time interval is 4 - 5 days, and not later than 6 days.
Regarding the number of injections recommended by me, it is conditional.
If a person is afraid to have too great a local reaction from the in-
jection of 2 cc. at the first injection, he may be given 1 cc., and then,
after 4 - 6 days, 1 or 2 cc., after which the final injection of 2 cc.
should be given. That is, at least 4 cc. should be given at intervals
of from 4 - 6 days. I believe I wrote you yesterday that persons should
not depend on the vaccination exclusively. This should be emphasized,
so that persons will take all known precautions and not allow themselves to be exposed to the disease.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Hideyo Noguchi Asst. Surgeon General
Henry R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
